The '#' (pound sign / hashtag) is used to interpret everything on the same line after it as a comment.

Comments are not treated as executable code by the Python interpreter and may be used to explain your code or what you're trying to accomplish. Put another way, it will help future you not hate past you.

tasks:
Rot13 is a monoalphabetic substitution cipher that replaces each character in a word with a corresponding letter thirteen places away in the alphabet as follows: 
a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s t u v w x y z
    ^   ^                         ^ ^ ^
    |   |                         | | |
    v   v                         v v v 
n o p q r s t u v w x y z a b c d e f g h i j k l m
using the table above, rot13('secret') yields a ciphertext of 'frperg'. Because the shift distance chosen is half the number of letters in our alphabet, rot13('frperg') therefore yields its original plaintext 'secret'. A more general way to observe this is that rot13(rot13(s)) = s for any string s. Implement rot13, encipher the phrase 
                  ATTACK AT DAWN
and provide the resultant ciphertext as the flag.

Charles Babbage, looking ahead to the sorts of problems his Analytical Engine would be able to solve, gave this example:

 What is the smallest positive integer whose square ends in the digits 269,696?
 —  Babbage, letter to Lord Bowden, 1837; see Hollingdale and Tootill, Electronic Computers, second edition, 1970, p. 125.

He thought the answer might be 99,736, whose square is 9,947,269,696; but he couldn't be certain.

Was Babbage correct?

tasks:
Bogosort shuffles a collection randomly until it is sorted. This is a perversely inefficient algorithm that should only ever be used facetiously. Its average run-time is O(n!) because the chance that any given shuffle of a set will end up in sorted order is about one in n!, and the worst case is infinite since there's no guarantee that a random shuffling will ever produce a sorted sequence. Its best case is O(n) since a single pass through the elements may suffice to order them. Try not to bogosort anything longer than 10 elements unless you have nowhere else to be for a while. Pseudocode: 
while not InOrder(list) do
   Shuffle(list)
done
Implement Bogosort and sort the following list: [38,4,201,14,25,19,78,9,193]

tasks:
ASCII is a text encoding standard that standardizes text representation and control signalling to enforce interoperability. A glyph (printable text character) or control character will always be represented by the same number when a device employs this standard. It's simple and compact - the tables below summarize both the hex and decimal representations of the character set. It can be thought of as indexing into an array for the purposes of this challenge. 
         2 3 4 5 6 7       30 40 50 60 70 80 90 100 110 120
        -------------      ---------------------------------
       0:   0 @ P ` p     0:    (  2  <  F  P  Z  d   n   x
       1: ! 1 A Q a q     1:    )  3  =  G  Q  [  e   o   y
       2: ” 2 B R b r     2:    *  4  >  H  R  \  f   p   z
       3: # 3 C S c s     3: !  +  5  ?  I  S  ]  g   q   {
       4: $ 4 D T d t     4: ”  ,  6  @  J  T  ^  h   r   |
       5: % 5 E U e u     5: #  -  7  A  K  U  _  i   s   }
       6: & 6 F V f v     6: $  .  8  B  L  V  `  j   t   ~
       7: ' 7 G W g w     7: %  /  9  C  M  W  a  k   u  DEL
       8: ( 8 H X h x     8: &  0  :  D  N  X  b  l   v
       9: ) 9 I Y i y     9: '  1  ;  E  O  Y  c  m   w
       A: * : J Z j z
       B: + ; K [ k {
       C: , < L \ l |
       D: - = M ] m }
       E: . > N ^ n ~
       F: / ? O _ o DEL

Using the in-built functions as necessary, return the ASCII encoding in hex of the following text: 

ATTACK AT DAWN
Use the hex bytes separated by only spaces as the flag.

    # Don't edit beyond this point!

tasks:
In number theory, a [pernicious number ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pernicious_number) is a positive integer such that the [Hamming weight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_weight) of its binary representation is prime -- that is, there is a prime number of 1s when it is written as a binary number. 

Examples:

The first pernicious number is 3, since 3 = 0b11 and 1 + 1 = 2, which is a prime. The next pernicious number is 5, since 5 = 0b101, followed by 6 (0b110), 7 (0b111) and 9 (0b1001). The sequence of pernicious numbers begins
3, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 24, ... ([sequence A052294 in the OEIS](https://oeis.org/A052294)).

The flag for this challenge is the ten millionth pernicious number.
starter_code:
